body.p: “The art of writing is so ancient, noble and marvelous,” the Jesuit Emanuele Tesauro states in the opening sentence of theCommentary(Il commentario), a panegyric on the shroud of Turin that he read in 1627 in the cathedral of Turin before the Savoy family, “that I cannot see who else but God could be the inventor.”1In Tesauro’s words, God allows the soul “to give birth to a highly secret concept [concetto] by means of a pen, to suckle it with ink, and to wrap it in the pages of a book like swaddling clothes.” God lets a concept live, grow, and “fly up to the spheres of human eyes.”2For Tesauro’s baroque sensibility, a concept has a visible expression. The page is the sheet or canvas where a “concept” reveals itself. This essay investigates the theological, devotional, visual, and literary connotations of Tesauro’s “concept” by analyzing his two panegyrics on the shroud of Turin,The Commentary(1627) andSympathy(1656).3

Tesauro explains the formation of a “concept” at the beginning of his vastThe Aristotelian Telescope(Il Cannocchiale aristotelico, first ed. 1654), the most important seventeenth‐century analysis of metaphorical expression: “The human intellect, like a pure mirror that is always the same and always different, expresses in itself the images of the objects that present themselves before it [the intellect]. These are what we call thoughts. As our mental discourse is nothing but an ordered context of these inner images, so is the external discourse nothing but an order of sensiblesigns, which are copied from the mental images, like types from their archetypes. But among these external signs, some are eloquent, others are silent, and others composed of silent eloquence and eloquent silence.”4Although he clearly echoes Aristotle’sDe anima3.4, Tesauro underscores that the intellect “expresses” the images it receives from the external world. Moreover, he identifies these external images with thoughts. An additional, essential detail to consider is Tesauro’s definition of human intellect as “mirror” (specchio), a concept that will play a fundamental role in our analysis of his texts on the shroud. Tesauro’s “mirror” elucidates and expands Aristotle’s concept of “writing table” (De anima430a1). Tesauro’s “always the same and always different” mirror highlights the mutual relationship between internal and external visibility. For Tesauro, to think means to reflect the infinite multiplicity of the real through an unrelenting production of visual metaphors, verbal and visible alike. For metaphors, Tesauro explicitly states in hisAristotelian Telescope, are “the most eloquent and fertile childbirth [parto] of human intellect.”5

Doubling Aristotle’s categorization, Tesauro posits eight forms of basic metaphors with three distinct structures: “simple metaphor,” “propositional metaphor,” and “argumentative metaphor.”6Out of the eight kinds, two metaphors work as the propulsive force of Tesauro’s rhetoric: the metaphor of “similitude” and that of “opposition.” Furthermore, Tesauro underscores that the fundamental goal of every metaphorical expression is the evocation of some form of “marvel” (meraviglia), which he defines as follows: “[Meraviglia, marvel] is the mind’s attentive contemplation of some new and remarkable object. Ignoring its origin, the soul is suspended and wishes to know it [the object’s origin].”7Marvel is a form of “brief rapture” (breve rapimento) that “alters man in a sensible way.”8Marvel first originates in the intellect and consequently overflows (ridonda) into the body. A “sudden ecstasy” (subita estasi) possesses the body, which is temporarily “speechless” (senza favella). In other words, a successful visual or verbal metaphor produces an “ecstatic” moment of inner suspension. In this internal silence man yearns to understand, to dive into the mystery summoned by marvel.

How does the shroud relate to the concept of marvel? What kind of silence and subsequent knowledge does the shroud produce in our inner “mirror,” the intellect, whose primary goal is to reflect the real through metaphorical expressions? As I will clarify in this essay, the shroud of Turin embodies the double nature of written and painted surface, but also of divine “mirror” in which the real is reflected. Tesauro’s metaphor speaks of an act of incarnation, in which a nonvisible idea becomes flesh and blood. The shroud has thus clear Eucharistic connotations, although Tesauro makes no direct allusion to the connection between the shroud and the Eucharist. He emphasizes that the shroud is at once the visualization of a concept (the Word’s incarnation) but also the embodiment of such a visualized concept, given that the shroud is “written” with the Word’s own blood. We could say that the shroud is at once name and thing, signifier and signified, metaphor and its exegesis. Moreover, in his second panegyric (Sympathy) Tesauro relates the shroud to St. Maurice, whose relics rested in the same cathedral of Turin. The shroud is “symbol,” and the saint’s body is its “agent,” that is, the saint’s relics actualize the shroud. In letting this image create an ecstatic suspension (Tesauro’s “marvel”), we perceive that the shroud is a mirror reflecting a universal biography. Like the relics of St. Maurice, we harbor an inner shroud, a symbolic image of the Word’s suffering and resurrection. The shroud demands that we become its linguistic “agents,” that is, that we mirror and enact its discourse of salvation.

The first and most influential treatise on the shroud isEsplicatione del lenzuolo ove fu involto il Signore(Interpretation of the sheet in which the Lord was enshrouded) by Alfonso Paleotto, Archbishop of Bologna. Paleotto’s seminal text came out in 1598, twenty years after the transfer of the shroud from Chambéry to Turin, the new capital of the state of Savoy. Paleotto’s book is at once a scientific description of the figure imprinted on the cloth and a meditative appropriation of the two images. The section “The Beauty and Measures of the Lord’s Body” (chap. 3) offers a detailed commentary on the two images reproduced at the beginning of his book (fig. 1). Paleotto adds a biblical quotation, “torcular calcavi solus” (I have trodden the wine press alone [Is. 63:3]), as if Christ himself commented on the image of his corpse. According to Paleotto, the Word wished to grant us a remembrance of his handsome face, which inThe Song of Songsthe bride had already contemplated in its powerful splendor.9If, as session 25 of the Council of Trent confirms, “ordinary” images “created by human art” can be used “to excite our celestial love,” how could we possibly refrain from contemplating the self‐portrait the Word granted us?10Paleotto’s devotional reading of the shroud could be read as a form ofaffetto(affective response), a key term of Italian seventeenth‐century literature. Based on Ignatius’sExercises,affettoindicates a literary text (prose or poetry) that aims at triggering a devotional response in the reader’s mind, a sort of “conversion of the heart,” as the Dominican Ignazio del Nente stresses in his important religious works.11In “The First Exercise,” Ignatius stresses that, if a meditation is “about something that can be gazed upon,” the imagination must first sketch a “physical space.”12In Paleotto’s text, the shroud is the space of the meditation on Christ’s passion. After the intellect has studied this inner space in greater detail, the will leads us “to deeper affections” [afectos].13In Paleotto’sEsplicatione, the affective response to the shroud has a strong apocalyptic connotation, which will be clarified in a later section of this essay. For Paleotto, the cloth marked with the Word’s blood signifies an interim time between his death and his Second Coming.14

Within this apocalyptic context the house of Savoy comes to play a prominent role. Tesauro’s first panegyric on the shroud (theCommentary) is a “praise” that, through the shroud, indirectly regards the Savoy family. The Savoy duchy had acquired the relic in 1453 from Marguerite de la Roche, the last descendent of the Charny family, which had owned the relic since the fourteenth century.15Tesauro holds that the house of Savoy had been chosen by the Word to preserve the visual memory of his human biography. For the shroud was not only the official relic of a ducal family, it was also its emblem, the visual synthesis of a historical project with openly apocalyptic connotations. Tesauro’s two texts envision the Savoy dynasty as the defender of Catholicism against foreign heretical countries. When Tesauro delivered his first panegyric in 1627, the Savoy duchy was already deeply involved in the Thirty Years War (1618–48), although his text makes no explicit reference to the European conflict.

The apocalyptic nature of theCommentaryis detectable in its opening pages. Tesauro writes that from the white sheet of a page like from a field sowed with “venomous seeds,” dead warriors arise to a renewed life.16Thanks to Livy, Horatius Cocles still fights alone against the “immense wave of steel” of the Etruscan army on the bridge over the Tiber.17The “Latin commentaries” grant a constantly renewed life to Hannibal and the soldiers who died in Cannae, but also to Scipio and the ashes of Carthage.18History is a series of biographical emblems with a perennial significance. The incarnate Word follows this interpretative model. Like Hannibal or Scipio, the emblem of Christ portrays a royal warrior fighting in an open field against his two main enemies, hell and death.19According to Tesauro, Christ wears a luminous armor and brandishes the powerful sword of his humanity, an echo of Rev. 9:11–16.20Christ’s emblem reminds us that his victory was hard earned. His hands are wounded, and his chest is bloody and torn. Hanging from the cross, he seems defeated rather than victorious.

The opening pages of Tesauro’sCommentaryevoke a visual hybrid, a double image (Christ at once dying on the cross and fighting as a brave king). Through this paradoxical image, Tesauro defies a facile rational apprehension. The viewer, baffled and surprised by this “marvelous” juxtaposition, feels compelled to follow and embrace Tesauro’s complex exegesis. This emblem of the Word is the object of a “commentary” that the Jesuit Tesauro, like a historian of antiquity, composes to express the silence imposed on the “marveled” mirror of the mind. Tesauro makes clear that “commentary,” a term often indicating biblical exegesis, cannot be applied to the emblem of the Word as a historian would use it to describe his composition of a secular biography. What does “to comment” mean in the context of the Word’s experience of suffering and death?

For Tesauro, the events registered in the Old Testament foreshadow Christ’s biography. Let us take, Tesauro continues, the story of King Ahasuerus in Esther. Two officers in the king’s office plotted to assassinate Ahasuerus, but the faithful Mordecai heard about this conspiracy and saved him, and the two officers went the gallows.21Tesauro adds that “the king reported the incident in the Annals.”22This biblical story is both historical event and allegory of Christ’s biography, that is, it is both real and metaphorical. Tesauro compares “King Ahasuerus to the king of heaven, the good Mordecai to his holy humanity, and the two conspirators to the devil and death.”23Moreover, in Esther, King Ahasuerus is at once main character, historian, and commentator. Similarly, the primary transcriber and interpreter of the Word’s emblematic biography is the Word himself.

The shroud is the Word’s commentary on his human biography. However, unlike the annals of King Ahasuerus, the shroud is also the irreplaceable self‐portrait composed by its author’s body. The image of the Word’s body marked on the cloth is at once text and exegesis. The blood he shed during the crucifixion is the ink he used to compose his text‐portrait. Finally, the letters of his writing create the overall image of his bleeding corpse.24We can infer that, in Tesauro’s text, the shroud of Turin is first and foremost an emblem. According to Renaissance emblematic theories, an emblem is a communication that blends in verbal and visual components. In “Treatise on Emblems,” the final section of theAristotelian Telescope, Tesauro defines an emblem as a “familiar symbol composed of a figure and words, which through a thesis [argomento] manifests a particular statement [documento] on human life.”25

Tesauro also states that an emblem is close to animpresa, which is also made of an image plus a motto.26Unlike an emblem, animpresamanifests a “particular and heroic thought” of a single individual.27Animpresais a private communication.28The most appropriate form ofimpresais a shield, an artifact that at once reveals and protects someone’s intentions. It is also possible to create an “emblematicimpresa” by merging the form of an emblem (an understandable image) with the goal of animpresa(a private and “heroic” insight).29For Tesauro, the sceneries (apparati) built for saints or deceased princes are “emblematic [imprese].” These objects at once regard a unique person and express “a general and virtuous statement [documento].”30“Documento” refers to the mottoes accompanying the image. An explicit epigram may make a figure closer to an emblem, whereas an obscure sentence may signify animpresa. However, by “statement” (documento) we must also intend what the viewer apprehends as private, invisible nourishment. Thisdocumentocorresponds to the “soul” (anima) of animpresa.

To glean a better understanding of this key term, it will be useful to consider the use of the termdocumentumin Christian tradition. InBenjamin Major, Richard of St. Victor uses the termdocumentumin his analysis of the two highest forms of contemplation: above reason (fifth form) and beyond reason (sixth form). Recalling Exod. 25:18–20, where God orders Moses to build a sanctuary and, at both sides of the oracle, to place two cherubim facing each other, their faces turned toward the propitiatory, Richard recommends that we “hammer out the form of angelic similitude in ourselves,” since “cherub” stands for “fullness of knowledge.”31Respectful of this divine “pattern” (documentum) and “testimony” (documentum), we should “spread out the wings of our cherubim” and long “to meet the grace of a showing.”32 Documentois thus both inner nourishment and the ritual leading to that spiritual nourishment (God himself explains how the two cherubim must look at each other but also face toward the propitiatory). Let us remember that the worddocumentumderives from the Latindocere(to teach) andmens(intellect). As spiritual food,documentoevokes the Eucharist, as Thomas writes in the hymnPange lingua: “let the old law yield to the new rite” (antiquum documentum novo cedat ritui).33

Contradicting most Renaissance theorists who believe that the figure is the “body” (corpo) of theimpresaand the motto is its “soul” (anima), Tesauro holds that “the signifying sign is the body” and “the signified concept is the soul.”34For Tesauro, “the [impresa] is a miraculous composition whose soul is outside of the body.” If the most common and correct form ofimpresais the shield, Tesauro concludes that animpresahas “its visible signifier in the shield and its intelligible signified in the mind.”35We could thus infer that the shroud is a divineimpresa, in that it is a visible gesture that produces spiritual nourishment. The “body” of this divineimpresais the Eucharist, which is Christ’s body through an act of transubstantiation, and the motto is the shroud of Turin, which is “written” with the Word’s blood. The “soul” is our inner appropriation and response to the Word’simpresa.

In his first panegyric on the shroud, Tesauro stresses that only a “sublime person” is able to write a “sublime commentary” of his own biography, as Julius Caesar did inThe Gallic War. Tesauro contends that the body inscribed on the shroud is foreshadowed in a passage from the book of Ezekiel, when God sends six men to slaughter the idolaters living in Jerusalem. Among these six mysterious executioners was a man “dressed in linen, with a scribe’s ink‐horn in his belt” (Ezek. 9:2).36God orders this man clothed in linen to place the mark “Tau” on the foreheads of those who mourn over the abominations committed in Jerusalem (Ezek. 9:4).37Later, after the killing, the same man dressed in linen scattered burning coals over the city (Ezek. 10:2).

According to Tesauro, the Son of God, the “sublime” writer of his own commentary, appears to the prophet as a scribe. His writing is first and foremost a sign of judgment and salvation (he marks the foreheads of those who do penance), but also of cleansing (he throws burning coal over the city). The linen cloth covering the body of the divine scribe will later become page and written text. Tesauro writes that, as a new Caesar, the divine scribe competes with himself, since he is at once supreme warrior and supreme historian of his own deeds. But as a written text, the divine scribe finds his literary model in Moses’s Decalogue.38If the two tablets contained the words that God dictated to Moses, in the two figures marked on both sides of the shroud God later revealed that the body of his Only‐Begotten Son brought his law to its fullness.

In the shroud, God is “author and autograph, printer and printed text.”39The medium that connects the divine author to his divine manuscript is the Word’s body whose blood is the very ink used to compose God’s visible text of salvation.40Christ’s corpse marked on the linen by his own blood is a hieroglyphic, that is, a symbolic and metaphorical expression made of one and only one figure.41Aristotle himself, Tesauro continues, holds that a “heroic and distinguished style” necessarily entails “poetic images and metaphorical connections.”42For Tesauro, hieroglyphics and figures of speech are typical components of divine communication. How could the divinity express his royal concepts but through a self‐portrait in human forms? And why is the Son called “Word,” if not to signify that he arises as image from the “Living Principle”? In the beginning, Tesauro holds, was God’s metaphor, the Word, his visible hieroglyphic.43God created humankind in the image and likeness of his Word, his original “figure of speech.”

Although Adam and Eve were expelled from the Garden of Eden, the human race still retains a deformed perception of God’s original “metaphor.” “Beatification,” Tesauro explains, is the mind’s “reformation,” that is, man’s transformation from stained glass to clear mirror of God’s “metaphor,” the Word. God’s Only Begotten is the original metaphor who, when he became incarnate, transformed himself into a new “figure,” for he turned into the image and likeness of God. Later, after his resurrection, he returned to the Father as a new “transfigured” image. Augustine may help clarify this point of Tesauro’s reasoning. InDe trinitate, Augustine offers an exhaustive analysis of his fundamental view of the “reformation” of man’s image‐likeness to the Word as the Father’s “figure.” The mind, Augustine contends, has a trinitarian structure analogous to God’s Trinity.44Consciousness (memoria) relates to the Father, knowledge (intelligentia) to the Son, and love (amor) to the Holy Spirit. Throughmemoriathe mind initiates a process of reformation, which can only occur “according to the image of God” (secundum imaginem Dei).45In Augustine’s view, our mind will perfectly conform to the image of God (it will become its perfect mirror) only at Doomsday.46One could infer that, according to Augustine, the mind’s process of reformation is an act of listening to the Father’s “figure of speech,” the Word, so that the mind can conform to his discourse.

In the opening section of theTelescope, by the title “Divine Wit,” decades later Tesauro will clarify some of the above concepts on God’s expression. God, Tesauro argues, always addresses men and angels through “heroic [imprese], figurative symbols.”47“Divine mythology” is at once literal, tropological, allegorical, and anagogical.48By “mythology” (mitologia), a term he does not explain in detail, Tesauro seems to mean God’s “physical actions,” which later become sacred narratives.49God’s interventions in the world always express a “heroic,” “marvelous” significance, which men later attempt to fathom through exegetical dissection (the four levels of exegesis).

The two images impressed on the shroud synthesize God’s “mythic” presence in human history. In the panegyric, Tesauro contends that God alluded to the Word’s dual nature when he said to Moses “You shall not see my face” and “You shall see my back.”50The two‐sided shroud is a literal manifestation of the divine (the frontal side) and human (the back side) nature of Christ.51In the dynamic rapport between the two parts of the shroud Tesauro identifies theenargeiaof divine expression. In Tesauro’s words,enargeia“expresses human actions as if they presented themselves faithful to the eyes and not to the ears.”52The shroud is the highest exemplar of divineenargeia, for this cloth is not a static image but rather (as a mythic representation) a portrait in motion, a figurative discourse that opens itself to infinite forms of apprehension. Let us remember that, for Quintilian, “vividness” (ornatumorenargeia) “is more than mere perspicuity, since instead of being merely transparent it somehow shows itself off” (se quodam modo ostendit).53

According to Tesauro, the two parts of the shroud lend themselves to a number of tropological readings. If the back side may represent the Old Testament (a divine figure turning his back to the present), the front side is the New Testament (a divine presence approaching the viewer).54The source of Tesauro’s comparison could be the Dominican Camillo Balliani’s lengthyRagionamenti della Sacra Sindone(first ed. 1610).55Tesauro also states that in the shroud we may recognize a figure that falls and one that arises, symbols of Christ’s death and resurrection. Finally, the figure that looks at us and the one that moves away may signify the embrace of those justified by the Word’s grace and the rejection of the sinners.56If all things came into being through the Word (John 1:3), the shroud is the final disclosure of the Word’s compassion. The shroud “forewarns that last day” when God will open the “divine book of the shroud” and “will force the Enemy of Christ and the damned souls to read their condemnation written in the characters of blood.”57As Paleotto’sEsplicationehad already stated, the shroud fore‐signifies the apocalypse. At Doomsday, our bodies will see their eternal condition reflected in the shroud. Like the incarnate Word’s, our lives will acquire the stillness of “emblematic [imprese],” at once memorials of a personal past and hieroglyphics of God’s justice.

As Tesauro will clarify in his second panegyric on this subject (Sympathy), the shroud manifests the “sympathy” (simpatia) that unites the Word to us. If we let the shroud “marvel” our intellect (our inner “mirror”), we perceive that the shroud is a visual form of self‐recollection in that, by remembering Christ’s human experience, we glean an insight on our own humanity. In Balliani’sRagionamenti, Tesauro could find an explicit reference to the shroud as a form of meditation: “If you wish to please Christ, to receive Him correctly, to conform to Him, to bury yourself with Him, and to resuscitate with Him, you must construct a clean shroud within your heart and soul.”58As Balliani confirms in hisRagionamenti, “the shroud helps us form the truthful image and similitude of God’s Son.” It supports us in our attempt to become “the perfect similitude of Christ.”59The shroud is thus similar to a “mirror” in which “we contemplate” our progressive resemblance (our reformation) to Christ’s humanity.60We could say that the “marvel” of the shroud reminds us that a basic “sympathy” ties the incarnate Word to us.61In other words, the shroud of Turin is a visual narrative concerning both the Word’s and our own biography. The shroud of Turin is indeed a “sympathetic” artifact.

The sympathy between the incarnate Word and human beings is the theme of Tesauro’s second panegyric on the shroud. WithSympathy(1654), written two years after the first edition of theAristotelian Telescope, Tesauro evokes a tenet of Renaissance natural philosophy, which held that “nature consisted of an almost infinite number of processes” linking every physical element to one another.62This natural “process” (sympathy) was essentially an infinite chain of metaphorical connections. For Tesauro, “sympathy” in fact indicates a rhetorical process of associations. “Sympathy,” Tesauro writes at the beginning of this panegyric, is the work of “divine providence, which produces no casual events.”63We might say that, as a successful rhetorician shows unexpected connections between seemingly unrelated linguistic signs, so does divine providence speak through “marvelous” affinities that defy the basic categories of time and space.

Delivering this panegyric in the basilica of Turin, Tesauro poses an audacious “sympathetic” connection between the shroud; the cardinal Maurice of Savoy (1593–1657), who strongly advocated the construction of a new chapel for the shroud; and the legendary martyr St. Maurice. Charles Emmanuel of Savoy had transferred the saint’s sword, his ring, and most of his body from the monastery of Agaunum (St. Moritz) to Turin in 1591.64The subtitle of Tesauro’s panegyric is in fact “On St. Maurice and the Holy shroud.” St. Maurice being of special significance for the Savoy family, Tesauro dedicated a second panegyric to this saint by the titleThe Armored Fortress(Il forte armato), which evokes the “fortress of St Maurice” (Il bastione San Maurizio) built in defense of the city. St. Maurice had acquired a particular prominence in the Savoy family in 1572, when Pope Gregory XIII recognized the new order of the “Chevaliers of Saints Maurice and Lazarus” that Emmanuel Filbert had created to fight the enemies of the Catholic faith.

Given Tesauro’s insistence on St. Maurice, let us mention only the main points of his life. The crucial document regarding the martyr Maurice and his companions isPassio Acaunensium martyrumby the bishop of Lyon Eucherius (450–55).65Maurice’s “blessed passion,” Eucherius writes, took place under the Emperor Maximian (AD 250–310), who “slaughtered and murdered” the followers of the Christian faith in different provinces of the empire.66At that time, Eucherius continues, within the emperor’s army existed a legion called “Theban, made of six‐thousand six‐hundred soldiers.”67When this legion arrived in Agaunum (St. Moritz today, in Switzerland), Maurice and his companions refused to engage in pagan sacrifices because they themselves were Christian. The emperor massacred this disloyal legion. The Savoy order of “Maurice and Lazarus” was under the aegis of this model of military allegiance to the true faith. The transfer of parts of Maurice’s body to the Turinese cathedral where the shroud also found its abode was a highly symbolic act, as if the saint’s relics and the Word’s shroud were meant to reside in the same sacred place. The shroud and the relics would enhance each other’s significance, and together they would bless the royal family of Savoy.

How can he possibly fathom the depth of divine providence that leaves no event to mere chance? Tesauro asks in the opening sentence ofSympathy.68“Today,” the divinity has formed a “problem” (problema) that the human mind cannot easily dismiss or solve. In the “solemn mausoleum” of Turin, divine providence has gathered the “Great Maurice” (Maurice of Savoy) and the holy shroud, but also the body of the martyr Maurice.69If the created world exists under the aegis of divine providence that controls the flight of every bird, the movement of every wave, and the falling of every branch from every tree, this “marvelous” occurrence must harbor a meaning.

More than any other of Tesauro’s previous discourses, this panegyric will address the “movements and the conjunctions” of what exists, the “blood” (sangue) of the created world.70With their “apparently casual correspondences,” the stars visible in a clear night sky stage the invisible cohesion of the world. We are unable to fathom their dynamics, although we know that the stars alter seasons, invigorate animals and plants, and secretly affect our “human microcosm.” Similarly, aren’t the martyrs’ bodies the greatest stars in the vault of Mother Church, our heaven on earth?71As the stars influence the creation through their rotations, so did the martyrs’ bodies and the Word’s shroud exert positive effects whenever they were moved from one location to another. “Everything you see in the sky [and] on earth,” Tesauro concludes, “is replete with hatreds and loves, concordances and discordances, sympathies and antipathies.”72

Tesauro writes that, as the scriptures and Aristotle confirm, blood (sangue) springs from the heart and contains a human being’s “sensitive soul” (the faculty of the sensitive soul present in animals).73Blood is the locus of every natural sympathy and antipathy. Thanks to blood’s inner qualities, two unrelated human beings may show unexpected similarities in their “faces or behaviors.”74But blood, being the abode of our sensitive soul, also unites two souls in a love bond. In other words, blood has a physical and spiritual connective power, an infinite metaphorical force. “The sympathy of the blood” (simpatia del sangue) causes a certain “boiling in the veins” and a “beaming of the eyes” when two friends meet.75

This form of sympathy that manifests itself in the body is called “natural” (naturale) and relates to two other kinds of sympathetic connections: “imaginary” (fantastica) and “rational” (razionale). In this three‐part concept of sympathy, Tesauro summarizes a rhetorical process in which “human discourse” (human discorso) holds the primary position. According to Tesauro, “rational sympathy causes the imaginary [sympathy], and because of its influence on blood the imaginary brings about the natural.”76Conversely, a natural sympathy produces internal images, which lead to discourse, “so that a natural love eventually becomes a virtuous habit.”77

Blood is thus a substance that harbors a linguistic power. For Tesauro, after the body’s death, blood maintains an expressive energy. Many Renaissance writers hold that, when a murderer approaches his victim’s corpse, blood oozes out of the dead body’s wounds.78How could we possibly deny that blood also possesses a unifying sympathetic power? Even after their death, Tesauro writes, quoting from Gregory the Great, the apostles Peter and Paul could not live distant from each other. Attempts to distance the remains of the two apostles were always accompanied by sinister events.79Their mutual love still echoes in their sympathetic relics.

But “whose blood was more sympathetic than Christ’s?” Tesauro concludes.80When the Word became incarnate, Tesauro states, borrowing from St. Paul, he shared his brothers’ nature so that he would become pure passion.81The Word as the embodiment of divine compassion assumed “the gentlest and most benign blood” in order to communicate “a sympathetic and natural compassion” toward all of humanity. The incarnate Word expressed his compassion in a number of occasions by weeping at a human affliction. Since tears are “a limpid distillation coming from the purest blood of the heart,” Christ shared his blood with the Magdalene when he was moved by her cry, when he cried at his friend’s tomb, and when he contemplated the walls of Jerusalem.82As the Word brought out his compassionate blood through his tears, so did his disciples and the crowds that followed him feel physically drawn toward him, toward his blood. Christ’s blood had and still has “a magnetic sympathy.”83

We could say that the bloodstains on the shroud signify the conjunction of divine compassion and human history. These stains mark the Word’s openness (his wounds) toward the creation, but they are also our invocation to the divinity. Tesauro draws an astonishing comparison between the shroud and the book ofLeviticus, where we read that, after shedding the blood of the propitiatory victim in the temple, the High Priest would bring a “particle” (particella) of this blood into the tabernacle and would sprinkle it on the veil.84This “mysterious figure” (misteriosa figura), “figure” meaning the ritual described in the Old Testament, foreshadows the shroud. If the victim signifies the “crucified humanity,” the temple is a “figure” of the Mount Calvary, and the tabernacle means the sepulcher. Moreover, God’s sanctuary symbolizes the Savior’s body, and the veil of the temple is the shroud. This is why, Tesauro adds, “in the same day, Christ marked the shroud [with his blood] and the veil of the temple was split.”85The tearing of the veil is also a figure of the shattering of the figurative correspondence between the Old and the New Testament. When the veil was torn apart, “the mystical sense yielded to the literal sense; the figure [figura] yielded to its figured meaning [figurato]; the conceptualized object [ideato] to its concept [idea]; and the copy to its original.”86

Following this chain of correspondences, we could infer that the shroud both tears apart the link between figure (image) and its figured meaning (what that means) and reenacts it. The shroud is an “eloquent” book that “speaks with words of blood,” as the scriptures foretell in the story of Abel. “What a marvelous contraposition between Christ and Abel,” Tesauro writes, “between victim and victim, between shedding and shedding, between wounds and wounds, between blood and blood, between sepulcher and sepulcher, between voices and voices.”87

At the beginning of divine revelation lies a profound “marvel.” Abel’s “antipathetic” blood spoke at the beginning of the scriptures whereas Christ utters his “sympathetic” words of blood and compassion at their closure. Although he finds this simile in Balliani’sRagionamenti, Tesauro adds that the incarnate Word also introduced new figurative meanings into old figures of speech (murder, wounds, sepulcher, blood, and voice).88The shroud is both tangible result and figure of this rhetorical renovation. For it is the figure of Christ, but it is also a figure of (his) speech. “Christ is dead and is still speaking,” Tesauro writes, “he is at once dead and alive.”89The shroud is thus both literal and figurative language. Similar to what David Tracy states in regard of the expression “God is Love,” we understand that the shroud exists within the tension between the two levels of signification.90The impossibility of separating the two rhetorical levels (literal and figurative) is of great importance for Tesauro. He holds that now Christ does not suffer or invoke the Father in an “expressed manner” (espressamente), but rather in an interpretative one (interpretativamente) because he “continues to represent the vestiges of His mournful passion to the Father.”91

At the beginning of this essay, we saw that, in the opening part ofCommentary, Tesauro states that “in the beginning” are imageless concepts and not images. Concepts then metamorphose into figures and finally, by “flying up” beyond the “spheres” of the interlocutor’s (or reader’s) mind, return to their original conceptual nature. In the second panegyricSympathy, Tesauro contends that figurative expression is in fact a manifestation of compassion and grief, of emotional participation. Quoting from Seneca’s fortieth epistle to Lucilius and from the book of Wisdom, Tesauro reminds us that images spring from a “distant and impatient longing.”92If Seneca speaks of “pictures of absent friends,” the biblical author foreshadows Christ’s death on the cross and the shroud. The book of Wisdom describes a “tender father who, when death stole his beloved son away, he stole him back from death by forming a very similar simulacrum (similissimo simulacro).”93At the origin of language thus lies the Father’s mournful longing for the Son, as if the sacrifice and death of the Son were the actual core of the divine.94“Who was the inventor of images,” Tesauro asks himself, “but the ingenious love of a tender father” who formed a picture of his son?95We have seen that, for Tesauro, in the beginning was the Word as metaphor of the Father.

For Tesauro, the shroud is the figure of a divine disclosure (the divine as mourning of an absence). He states that John 20:12, on the two angels sitting where Christ’s corpse had been, stages this central concept. “[Mary] saw two angels” echoes the two parts of the shroud.96“In white” corresponds to the color of the cloth. “Sitting” indicates a meditative posture. The two angels (one sitting where the head of Christ had been, the other at his feet) seem to be meditating on an empty space (“where the body of Jesus had been”), as if “they loved to contemplate Christ dead better than resurrected in His glory.” Tesauro holds that the two angels conversing with the Magdalene also figure the “sympathetic” harmony that resulted from Christ’s death. Heaven and earth equally participate in the sympathetic blood shed by the incarnate Word.97

The blood’s original divine nature is still detectable in the fact that, similar to the Eucharist, it urges us to recall the Word’s sacrifice. However, unlike the Eucharist, this blood does not summon the Word’s presence. We find an analysis of this crucial issue in the Theatine Agaffino Solaro’sSindone evangelica(1627). Contradicting Thomas Aquinas and Francisco Suarez, who believe that no relic can derive from Christ’s body because he resurrected with his entire humanity, Solaro holds that the blood on the shroud does belong to Christ. Christ chose to leave particles of his blood on the shroud in memory of his crucifixion, but this blood has a nonhypostatic nature, because it did not resurrect with the rest of his body.98If we maintain the comparison to an emblematic structure, we could say that the nonhypostatic blood on the shroud composes the motto of a divine emblem, whose “body” is the Eucharist. The “soul” of this sacred emblem is our dining at the table of the Word’s emblem.

If the bloodstained shroud echoes the Eucharist, the linen cloth spread on the altar of a church echoes the shroud.99I have already explained that, faithful to a topos of Italian baroque style, Tesauro founds his writing on two basic metaphors, what he calls “similarity” and “opposition.” Borrowing again from Balliani’sRagionamenti, Tesauro posits a direct mirroring between Christ and the linen cloth.100“What is linen,” he asks the reader, “but a plant born in tears?” Describing how linen is produced, Tesauro writes: “It [linen] is pulled away from its native earth, then drowned in water, then torn, lacerated, and beaten.” Later, it is “stretched on the cross of a loom and pierced thousands of times.” As the prophet foresaw (Isa. 43:17), linen is the symbol of martyrdom. Consequently, “what is the shroud but a martyr in cloth? What is a martyr but a shroud in flesh? Or better yet, what is the shroud but the idea [idea] of all martyrs?”101Being the visible sign of martyrdom, Tesauro hypothesizes that the shroud, and not the cross, will become visible at Doomsday. The “the sign of the Son of Man in heaven” that Christ mentions to his disciples (Matt. 24:30) will be the shroud stained with his blood.102Before sending his angels to gather his elect, the Word will show his own shroud, the supreme “vestige” and emblem of his incarnation. The shroud in Turin will be reflected in the heavens, as a final agreement between earth and sky.

The relics of St. Maurice were brought to rest next to the shroud in the Turinese cathedral by a complex “sympathetic” movement. First of all, Tesauro contends that the “Theban Legion” is the real “militia of the shroud,” in the sense that it closely recalls the Word’s human experience.103Given that it originated in Egypt, the Legion of St. Maurice was meant to echo the exile of the baby Jesus from his fatherland.104St. Maurice as symbol of an entire legion followed the incarnate Word and “copied” his human vicissitudes. According to Tesauro, Maurice recalls both the incarnate Word and the angel Gabriel who witnessed the crucial events of the Word’s human biography. Tesauro underscores that, in hisPassioof St. Maurice, St. Eucherius calls the Theban martyrs “the angelic legion.”105Since in Greek “angelicus martyr” equals “angelicus testis” (witness), it is easy to identify Maurice as the human reflection of the angelic Gabriel, who was both “custodian and minister of the Savior.”106Tesauro contends that Gabriel, the angel who announced the Savior’s birth to Mary, was also the “Angelus Domini,” who sat alone at the Word’s sepulcher, suggested that the holy family leave for Egypt, and finally comforted Jesus in Gethsemane.107According to Tesauro, as in the sepulcher Gabriel functioned as “martyr” (in the sense of “witness”), so does now the martyr Maurice serve as the angel custodian of the shroud.

At the end of this beautifully crafted series of identifications, Maurice “contemplates Christ’s martyrdom in His image and his own martyrdom in Christ’s.”108If the shroud is the visible reminder of an internal shroud that lies dormant within us, the image of the angelic witness Maurice contemplating his own biography in the shroud is a powerful synthesis of this process of self‐enlightenment. In the shroud Maurice recognizes the sense of his martyrdom in the light of the Word’s biography. The image of the shroud is the emblem of our human experience. By visiting the cathedral of Turin, we become “witnesses” of a divine “sympathetic” mirroring between the shroud and its angelic martyr. To meditate on the shroud means to let the reflection between the shroud and the relics of Maurice be reflected on our inner “mirror,” the intellect.109

But how does the shroud‐relics reflection operate? What does it mean to participate in a divine mirroring? Tesauro again offers an intrinsically rhetorical interpretation of some tenets of Renaissance hermetic thought.110He reminds us that the inner qualities of a given “agent” (agente) become apparent when it is connected to its “symbol” (simbolo).111As agent, the relics speak forth the beneficial qualities of the shroud. The shroud, we could say, is here a noun, whereas St. Maurice’s body is its actualization. In other words, the name “shroud” means the relics of the martyr Maurice, and conversely the martyr’s relics are symbolized in the shroud. “Shroud” is the proper name of the relics. The link between an “agent” or object and its name or “symbol” can be in fact seen as a movement from potentiality (in potenza) to actuality (in atto).112To explain this crucial point, Tesauro reminds us that Paul, “already destined to martyrdom,” believed that he carried the “stigmata” of the Lord in his body.113

Paul had become a perfect mirror of the crucified Christ. For Tesauro, the Word was a sun enlightening the martyr apostle and reflected himself through him. The shroud, Tesauro adds, is the visible echo of Paul’s inner stigmata. But, unlike Paul, we are unable to become pure reflections of this luminous sun. Our contemplation of the sacred cloth in fact beclouds its luminosity. Our intellect is a smudged mirror.114In similar terms, writing on 2 Cor. 3:18, in his epistle 147 (De videndo Deo) Augustine holds that, after Christ’s resurrection, our faces are mirrors reflecting God’s glory, but those who reject Christ have placed a veil over their faces.115We have seen that, in Tesauro’s Catholic view, we still retain a perception of the Word as the Father’s “metaphor.” For Augustine, the Bible as well is a mirror (speculum) reflecting our truthful image.116InAnatomia sacra(Sacred anatomy, 1685), a powerful manual of meditation on the shroud, the Theatine Vittorio Amedeo Barralis dedicates an entire chapter on the image of Christ’s “blindfolded eyes,” in which he opposes Christ’s physical blindness to the sinners’ inner inability to see themselves reflected in the Word’s image.117InSympathy, Tesauro contends that the Word has placed the relics of Maurice next to the shroud, because the relics work as “a third and firm mirror that excites that beneficial power of this sun.”118

As “agent” of the shroud, the body of Maurice is at once “firm mirror” and shield. “Never like now,” Tesauro writes, “we need his [Maurice’s] assistance given the numerous armies and trumpets blaring around us, the numerous ominous appearances of infectious influences close to us.”119For Tesauro, the Savoy duchy is a new sacred land afflicted by external and internal menaces. Not only do heretical armies threaten this Catholic territory, the air itself seems to be infected with noxious presences. As shield, the martyr Maurice of the Theban Legion is asked to protect the land that Christ has chosen to preserve his sacred cloth. The panegyric concludes with a prayer to the martyr: “Let us implore our Martyr so that he implore [God to grant us] public peace, physical and spiritual health, a more salubrious air [and] a concordance between God, the world, and ourselves.”120In Tesauro’s words, entering the perfect mirroring between the shroud and the relics, we “implore” the relic “to implore” the shroud.

We have seen that the shroud is the Word’s “symbol” and the relics are its “agents.” We glean a clearer understanding of this rhetorical and linguistic connection if we read it in the light of Renaissance notions of emblematic expression. In an earlier section of this essay, I explained Tesauro’s innovative theories. I pointed out that Tesauro believes in the existence of visual hybrids, some sorts of emblematicimprese, at once “heroic” and personal messages expressed through general visual statements. Contradicting a tenet of the Renaissance concept of emblem, in theTelescopeTesauro contends that “the [impresa] is a miraculous composition whose soul is outside of the body.”121For Tesauro, the “miracle” of animpresalies in the fact that its message turns into a personal, nonvisible insight. The “soul” of the shroud‐impresais the marvel brought about in the “mirror” of our intellect.

Tesauro clarifies further the concordances between the shroud and the martyr Maurice inIl forte armato, a brief panegyric entirely dedicated to St. Maurice. Offering a free interpretation of Luke 11:21 (“a strong man fully armed”), Tesauro again portrays Maurice as the “heroic” presence placed at the “entrance of the noble reign of Italy” to protect the peninsula against numerous external dangers, in this case identified with the heresies plaguing the rest of Europe.122Serving as custodian and witness (martyr,testis), Maurice has also the duty to defend “the canvas of the Savior.”123If inSympathyhe had focused on the blood on the shroud, inIl forte armatoTesauro dwells on the blood of the martyrs, which is “the blood of the Church.”124The martyrs’ blood is an affirmative response, a firm “yes” to the blood of the Word. Like the two‐part shroud, the martyr Maurice and thus his relics have a dynamic nature, for they express at once “stillness and movement, tribulation and peace.”125If the shroud as “emblematic [impresa]” has brought forth a “soul” within the blood of the martyr, so do his relics now possess a similar symbolic nature. The “contamination” from blood to blood, from soul to soul, has no end. This is the redeeming power of the martyr’s relics. Echoing the ending ofSympathy, Tesauro insists that the saint’s body safeguards “the air you breathe.”126

At the end of this avalanche of metaphorical connections, of “marvelous” associations, what final and conclusive role do we assign to the shroud, to the figure marked with the Word’s sympathetic blood? Emanuele Tesauro daringly states that in the beginning was the Father’s Metaphor, the Son, who became figure to share the metaphorical idiom of our “mirror,” the intellect. The dialogue between the divinity and human beings exists as reflecting metaphors. The blood of Christ is the quintessential manifestation of the intrinsically metaphorical nature of the real and of his infinite compassion. If we are mirrors blinded by the marvel constantly disclosed by divine compassion, our exegesis is a maze of hypothetical reflections, of hypothetical metaphorical comparisons. Paul’s words are clear: “Now we see only reflections in a mirror.”127In allowing the image of the crucified Word, the metaphor of the Father, to reflect its marvel on our beclouded mirror, we are invited to fathom our own metaphorical nature, our being nothing but visible echoes of the Father’s original metaphor. Christ is our biography. Like the martyr Maurice, the shroud’s “agent,” we are reflections of a luminous marvel of salvation.

David Tracy examines the tension between literal and metaphorical meaning in Christian religious language in “Metaphor and Religion: The Test Case of Christian Texts,” inOn Metaphor, ed. Sheldon Sacks (Chicago: University of Chicago Press, 1979), 89–104. Tracy focuses on two basic expressions: “The Kingdom of God is like” and “God is Love.” “The statement ‘God is Love,’” Tracy writes, “does not say literally what God is butproducesa metaphorical meaning for what God is like” (103). Tracy refers to Paul Ricoeur’s insistence on the concept of tension inThe Rule of Metaphor(trans. Robert Czerny [Toronto: University of Toronto Press, 2000], 247–56). Ricoeur speaks of “theecstaticmoment of language,” which is “the moment ofbelief,of ontological commitment” (249). Ricoeur summarizes the idea of “tension” within metaphorical truth as follows: “There is no other way to do justice to the notion of metaphorical truth than to include the critical incision of the (literal) ‘is not’ within the ontological vehemence of the metaphorical ‘is’” (255).

Compare Marino,Dicerie sacre, “La pittura,” pt. 1, 119. Marino compares God to a mirror that reflects the soul’s truthful image. If God withdraws, the soul becomes unable to see itself. The image of mirrors reflecting mirrors is a topos of baroque love poetry. The innumerable sonnets written in seventeenth‐century Italy on this subject aim to create a sense of labyrinthine astonishment, an inner vertigo, the baroque “marvel.” For example, see Giovan Battista Marino,Rime amorose, ed. Ottavio Besomi and Alessandro Martini (Ferrara: Edizioni Panini, 1987), sonnets 11–13. This series of poems is entirely dedicated to the topos of the mirror. The most complex and accomplished is the third in which Marino imagines that the mirror reflecting his beloved’s image was made of the tears he had shed and that had become a lucid surface (sonnet 13, verse 2, 61). “The angelic splendor of this goddess” (i.e., his beloved) has turned the mirror into a small heaven, since it reflects the woman’s luminosity (verses 3–4). Love has allowed the metamorphosis of the poet’s tears into mirror, so that his “beautiful sun” (his woman, verse 6) can see what he hides “in the mirror of my heart” (verses 7–8) and detect her beauty in the surface of his visible sorrow. The external mirror is thus a reflection of the poet’s inner mirror in which the luminous woman reflects upon her own image.

Ibid., 83. For Tesauro, the metaphor of the saint as shield is of great relevance. If inSympathyMaurice and the shroud are the shields of the Catholic Savoy family, inEdipo(Oedipus, 1661), Tesauro’s interpretation of Seneca’s tragedy, Oedipus is the shield that prevents the divinity from exerting his power of purification. In Tesauro’s tragedy, Oedipus holds a long monologue on the “voracious plague” that afflicts the city of Thebes. A praetor replies to the Oedipus that the heavens are merciful because “they oppose your [Oedipus’s] virtue like a shield against their own furor.” See Emanuele Tesauro,Edipo, ed. Carlo Ossola (Venice: Marsilio, 1987), 1.1, verse 4, 79, and verses 47–48, 80. We could thus say that, for Tesauro, Maurice is a sort of anti‐Oedipus who has made himself into a lucid mirror of the shroud (the shield reflecting divine will). The saint’s body is a transparent surface reflecting and “actualizing” the “symbol” of the shroud. By contrast, Oedipus’s ignorance of his sins is a darkened, blind shield that prevents the divinity from shining through.
